titlePart.supplied: Short Pieces from June 1914 Woman Rebel

sourceDesc.bibl: The Woman Rebel, Vol. 1, No. 4, June 1914, 32
Margaret Sanger Microfilm, Collected Documents Series C16:0546

div.head: Don't Miss It!
div.p: For a concise and lucid survey of the revolutionary movement of the world and sane interpretation of radical forces and programs, you should subscribe to "Land and Liberty," published at Hayward, California. The first number, published in May, was excellent; and the second number was better than the first. "LAND AND LIBERTY" throws light on passing events instead of indulging in vague and visionary theories about social salvation. It emphasizes the value of intelligent editorship in revolutionary papers. Let us hope that other revolutionary publishers may profit by the appearance of "LAND AND LIBERTY." Send one dollar for a year's subscription, or at any rate send a postcard for a sample copy.

div.head: Not Suppressed
div.p: Here is a typical front-page "story" of those newspapers who pride themselves on printing all the news that's "fit to print." It is from the N. Y. Evening Mail of April 16, and was NOT suppressed by the post-office authorities. It is a "good story" and an every-day comment on American "civilization."

p.q: "Mrs. Katherine Vogel, sixty-one years old, committed suicide in her apartment at 34 First avenue to-day by drinking carbolic acid.

div.p: "In the next room lay the body of a girl about twenty years old, the victim of an operation alleged to have been performed by Mrs. Vogel. The identity of the girl is not known. It is believed she was a professional dancer."
